The Pignose Hog 30 is a battery powered amplifier for electric guitar, electric bass, keyboards, microphone, and just about anything else that, according to the owner's manual "works at 20 watts, with 35 watts of peak power."  In reality, the 20 watts is probably the more accurate number, as I have a fairly inexpensive Washburn 30 watt bass amp that provides more sound at about "4" than the Pignose does turned all the way up (and with the funk bass switch activated, to boot).  This amplifier seems, though, to hold a charge nicely and would therefore seem to be the ideal amplifier to take along to any al fresco situation.  My 4 star review is bassed (spelling intentional) on the fact that it has a "5" tone for clean-tone electric guitar, but is more of a "3" for electric bass.  Mine seems to have an inherent buzz on F (10th fret, G string, electric bass).  The speaker looks fine, the screws are all tight, but there's a buzz.  I have tried three different basses and the buzz is most annoying on a short-scale bass, but it is noticeable on all three.  Cutting the treble and mid-range and boosting the bass on the amplifier helps quite a bit, but still this amplifier clearly emphasizes the upper harmonics.  At some point, it might be interesting to see what a larger speaker would do, although several non-Amazon reviews that I've read suggest that the relatively small (for a bass amp) speaker might not entirely be the culprit.  I would recommend the Pignose Hog 30 without question for guitarists (the buzz is not really noticeable on guitar, so it does seem to be connected somehow to the harmonic series (overtones) of the bass.  It is a crisp guitar amp and with effects pedals will do just about anything you'd need for practicing or for a small outdoor gig.  With a classical acoustic/electric, it is also quite nice, especially for the price.  On bass, it's just more fussy.  I did connect through an emulator pedal that changes the overtones and the tone was better; however, ideally an amplifier should not require the use of an effects pedal.  It is not a bad bass amp, provided that the music you are playing avoids the resonating frequency and the notes adjacent to it.  Since I play both bass and guitar, I am happy with the amp, and will use it for both.  If I only played bass, however, I might be looking for another battery powered amp.
summary: Five Stars for Guitar; Three for Bass

reviewText: Nice sticks, good if you're a loose grip drummer in need of comfortable grippable sticks. These feel nice and are very comfortable! Durable too. Would buy again.

I recently received a pair of these and haven't put them to the test yet, but 4 stars because I like the way they feel and look.  Unless they shatter in my hands (if they do I'll add to this review later, if and when...) I'm sure they'll do nicely.
summary: but 4 stars because I like the way they feel and look

reviewText:
Like any decent preamp, the SansAmp expands and refines the sound
of the electric bass, whether in the studio or playing live.

My friend has one and swears by it.

And I concur.
summary: Makes a bass sound fuller, more detailed

reviewText: Recommended by the instructor as high quality and good value.  Would recommend these, and other similar to anyone in need of new reeds.

These sticks reduce SO much of the vibrations!... but feel awkward to play with.

Sticks naturally vibrate off the surface you play them on; you may not notice as much on the toms or snare, but you can definitely feel vibrations in your hands when you hit a cymbal bell, play on the rims of the drums, and especially with rim shots.  From what I've researched, these vibrations can cause stress in your hands and/or arms depending on your technique and hit, and that's something to think about if you have had drum related injuries in the past or want to try avoiding an injury.  So the fact that these sticks really do decrease the vibrations is awesome because your hands absorb much less of the strain from each hit which in theory would lessen your chances of wrist or arm injuries or help those who have these injuries play drums.  This aspect of the stick is the reason why it gets the 4 starts.

The reason why I deducted a star is because the stick just not comfortable to hold and play with.  There seems to be rubber running through the inside of the stick which would explain why it feels heavy and unbalanced throughout the whole stick. The finish and bead and shaft are great; but I can't play comfortably with the anti-vibe sticks and it's not as much fun to drum with sticks that don't feel "good".  Wasn't for me, glad I tried it, may or may not work for you.
summary: Anti-vibration aspect of stick is great

reviewText:
Good sticks, very light weight. The sound they create is unique.

Great for rudiment practice or when you want your drums to quit down some example :a mellow song..

I recommend them, their a great option to have in the stick bag.

The material seems cheap, I am worried that any tiny little thing is going to scratch or mar the knobs, or heaven forbid, something might hit them the wrong way and they may just shatter. However, the acrylic is perfectly clear, the numbers are easily legible, and the grip is good, so cheap feeling is a relatively minor gripe. My biggest complaint is that the knurling on the inside of the knob doesn't seem to match the knurling on any potentiometer anywhere, so it's extremely difficult to get them ON to begin with. As much as I was terrified of cracking and breaking them getting them on, I couldn't get them flat and flush without taking a rubber mallet to the tops, which also made me worry about damaging the equally-expensive pots they were mounting to. And that creates the new problem of "I have no idea how I'm going to get them back off if I ever need to because they're stuck on so tight."

That hasn't stopped me from putting them on in place of the weird rippled barrels that came on my SG, and in place of the even more awful Fender-style top hats on my Telecaster thinline. I'm just glad that they don't say "volume" and "tone" on them. I'm not a huge fan of labeling something that's obvious, because to me it just looks tacky. I've bought several sets of these already and probably will end up buying more eventually, so I guess that's a good testimonial. But they are also the only game in town for this look, so it is what it is.

While certainly not a Rhode or MXL high end mic , this CAD is quite good. I record in a small room , and this captures my drum set well for overheads. A little room noise , but that's probably my cheap mic pre-amp. Overall a very good microphone.
summary: this CAD is quite good. I record in a small room

reviewText:
The set are a good replacement. Small thing, but the packaging is not user-friendly. The knobs are covered in thin clear flexible plastic, vacuum-packed so tightly to the card that even using a knife to try to cut through it was difficult. It was a needlessly tedious process.

The knobs set up higher than my old ones and even after pushing down with some force, they were still too high. I covered the knobs with a thick cloth and used a rubber mallet to gently rap on them until they were somewhat lower but the plastic is pretty thin and brittle so proceed with caution..
summary: Gibson Gear Set of 4 Les Paul Replacement Knobs

reviewText: I put these on a PRS SE245 to give it more of a vintage vibe. I succeeded but the pots on the guitar are a little stiff and these little top hats are hard to grab and spin like the speed knobs that I replaced. The numbers are hard to see but I adjust by ear so that doesn't bother me. The knobs are very light and the plastic feels cheap but they do look good.

These sticks were nice when I was recovering from carpal tunnel surgery on my hands but still needed to play.  Once I got my strength back I was breaking off tips constantly.  Now using the harder, heavier wood sticks again.  They did serve a purpose when I needed them.

Quality paper in a spiral bound notebook. The reason for 4 stars is the layout of the pages. There is a really small header (3/8") and a large footer (1"). If these were reversed, I'd give it 5 stars. However, this is my purely subjective opinion and writing style.
good if it's up close
Overall a good product
just get it !

it's a basic cardioid large diaphragm [1 inch dia] w/bass tilt true condenser mic that c/w/ adequate shockmount cage. it c/w/ zipper leatherette bag 4 the mic.
pros:
bargain price[less than $60.] mic is good build quality & the shock mount is ok 4 the price.
mic easily opened 2 change base tilt, the push button is clearly labeled & works smoothly.
works well plugged directly in2 zoom R16 digital recorder phantom powered mic input.
works well w/innogear 48volt phantom power supply jacked in2 zoom R6 non phantom powered mic inputs.
works well w/cad pop filter
it sounds [2 me] like it should given the  published frequency response.
the included mic description & frequency response [ well printed on coated poster stock ] is clear & gives u the info u need 2 use & operate the mic & is presented in the standard format established by the importers of the primo german makers like akg ,beyer or sennheiser, 40+ yrs ago. there is no poorly translated/presented chinese 2 english on or in the box it came in.
cad is american based mic manufacturer w/a large line of american made mics, making this mic in china so price is quite low & qc seems good.

cons:
shock-mount needs washers in the angle adjustment joint so it can b adjusted smoothly, tightened firmly & locked in position.
shock-mount mic clamp needs thicker felt so grip on mic body is secure enuf 2 hang mic upsidedown in overhead applications.
box it comes in is very thin w/no foam or bubble pack. it is not heavy enuf 2 use 4 storage like the heavyweight box that samson mics come in [& samson gives u a zipper closed fitted case that is very nice].
it wasn't free[ ! ].
summary: nice 4 the price cardioid large diaphragm [1" dia] true condenser mic

reviewText:
This review is a little useless if you want to know how the stock microphone sounds. I have no idea. Probably bad.

I bought this to do a microphone mod, in particular the Linear 87 mod. It's now my favorite studio vocal microphone and I've used it with many singers.

My opinion on the stock internals is that they're pretty low grade with poor consistency in DC voltages between units. The metal shell was poorly surfaced with rusty bits and messy coatings on the inside. The mounting metals are extremely weak, bending easily out of shape. This was actually beneficial for the mod since the new boards were slightly different in size, but still not good quality. Overall the EM shielding is good though.

I'll give this 4 stars for being a good base for modding. Check out the Linear 87 mod online.
summary: Used this for the Linear 87 Mod and I love it

reviewText: Nice sound, with some warm distortion.
summary: I like it. Not a neutral mic.

reviewText: This is a great product!!!  Strongly recommended.

Let me first state that,  I came from a Samsom Meteor Mic 2 years ago,  and a Blue Spark Digital from last summer.  This microphone out performs both in many aspects.  The mids are a tiny bit held back in my opinion.  But not terrible.  The lows and highs are definitely noticable. However,  it does seem a lil quiet (volume). Maybe I need a different preamp(using a Blue Icicle). Regardless,  this mic is above average and should suit your needs.  I use mine for music recording(rapping and singing) by the way.
Purchased for our community choir.  They add just the right touch to our Christmas contata performances.
Great finger cymbals
Very good for high hats or placing two of them over a drum set.  They're not a Neumann but for my busget they're close enough.
The finish looks very classy.  The build quality is superb.  Overall this is a pretty good mic.  I want to buy more.

Though I am not personally a belly dancer, I have heard from others that these finger cymbals are too thick and heavy to control easily while dancing. Though this is the "thin" model, they are still far thicker than the more generic finger cymbals on the market. That being said, these have a great sound and are beefy enough to cut through other sounds. The metal has a rough texture, which is good for adding friction to help make the cymbals ring/clap against each other, though that has the drawback of increasing the likelihood of accidental sounding while rubbing (compared to perfectly smooth cymbals).
It simple, works good. Just shake and spray and wipe to a shine. Makes my 58 ri Les Paul shine like a diamond.
Good ability for the price.
great polish....works well.....
Good buy for the $$$ spent

I was a little hesitant to purchase this mic at first because there weren't a lot of reviews on it and the price was low.  I figured that I'd give it a go and much to my delight it delivers.  No it's not a Neumann, it's not an AKG, it's not a fancy pants boutique mic.  It's a mic that delivers good sound at an unreal price.  It records well for electric amplified guitar as well as acoustic guitar.  I have not yet tried it for vocals or drums but I'm sure that it will stand up and do the job.  When I recorded my acoustic guitar I noticed that it has a brilliant top end that lets the strings sing clear and clean with a touch of sparkle.  It also captures enough low end to let you know that you've got some bottom rolling for your sound.  The construction of the mic seems good and the appearance is amazing.  CAD even gives you a cleaning cloth to wipe off finger prints.  The shock mount is solid. It looks a little thin but when you touch it you know that it's going to hold the mic just fine.  This mic doesn't have a pad and only hosts one sound pattern but it delivers.  The input connection is solid so you don't have to worry about a shorted connection.  There are a lot of mics out there and a lot of them can be used in a variety of different situations.  This one is a good choice for many.  I don't know if anyone has ever recorded a Grammy winning vocal with this mic but it's not out of the realm of possibility.  rock on.

I ordered this in mid July and it had an early August arrival date. It got here in mid August, a couple weeks late, but I wasn't in a huge rush to get it anyways. Well, it arrived and it's perfect. Words cannot describe how much cleaner my guitar is now! My pride and joy can shine and continue with its great tone. I would recommend this, and I would give it 5 stars if it was not for the shipping time.

So far so good.  i have done a little acoustic guitar and voice recording with it.
I did a lot of reading up on mics prior to buying.  I mostly got this based on price and availability, plus mostly decent reviews.

It is a bit more sensitive than my SM-58, so you can back up from it when you record, or turn down the levels on your mixer, or perhaps a bit of both. I have used it with a Tascam interface and my Ipad mini so far.  I like it a lot.  Its quiet, there is no extra hum or hiss in the recordings.

If you are a DIY person or modder, I have read that these can be upgraded with a few better parts for even better performance. I don't plan on doing that, but figured I would add to the discussions here.

I am using it with the Tascam ixz and a Behringer mixer.  I am able to monitor everything and not having any tracks bleeding over.  I am plugging the mic into the board, then line out of the board to guitar in of the Tascam. I plug my headphones into the Tascam and its working well.
Great microphone for the price. I'm happy with this. I use it for small production. It picks up the small sounds in the room which is awesome.
Nice, basic soprano recorder with carry case and fingering chart. I like to give these away to interested friends . I think everyone should have the opportunity to play an instrument.

I want to make two things clear up front.  1:  I am not a professional studio engineer, but I am a serious recording hobbyist who takes the art of engineering & recording as seriously as at the art of music itself.  2:  I fully realize the subjective parts of mic reviews and will avoid as many cliche's as I can.  Okay I'll keep this short, so lets go.

One thing I always remind people of with microphones is how important it is to realize the facts and golden rules of microphones.  For instance, one person's garbage mic is another gold standard go-to mic.  Also, what determines the class a mic sits in (beginner, intermediate, pro) is entirely misguided as those identifiers are almost entirely referring to the price point.  That's why everyone calls a $100 mic a budget mic and a $1000+ mic a pro mic.  The only other thing that determines pro from budget is how a company stands behind their engineering.  If you can send your mic in to the manufacturer and get a capsule replaced or otherwise have the mic repaired and sent back, I would say that partly qualifies a mic as pro level.  I could care less if a mic costs 20 bucks, if the company stands behind their product and I like the characteristics of the mic then it could be a "pro's" mic (the engineering isn't that complicated, just expensive to do).  The only way this could be disputed is that some higher end microphones are engineered exceedingly well to be absolutely neutral and don't contain sonic characteristics that otherwise color the neutral sound.  Anyways...

I have two of these microphones in my kit.  I generally only pull them out for room miking or for stereo spread miking in applications where I want to capture the transients better.  I generally do not use these alone on an instrument, they are usually always blended in with other mikes that are covering the same instrument from another place.

The key to being a good engineer is identifying the limitations of your equipment and knowing how to work around them, or at least knowing what the best mic is for the desired application.  This microphone in question is a small diaphragm cardioid condenser, so what does that tell us?  Typically small diaphragm mics are better at reacting to transients (sharp fast sounds) and since its a condenser it will have a better dynamic range (with volume and pickup) than say a dynamic or non-active ribbon mic.  They are also the lipstick style body designs so that means they can be placed almost anywhere because of their small size and simple design (compared to a clunky heavy tube LDC mic).

Some limitations are:

1.  You can't switch between polar patterns (no figure 8 or omni), but that's common here.  You wouldn't be using this design of a mic for omni or figure 8 uses anyways.

2.  Its made at a lower price point so that means lower quality parts and workmanship or quality control.  Though this is an unproven assumption, its easy to infer that if you don't treat the mic with great care, it could break very easily.  Also, I haven't checked, but does anyone know if CAD will fix or replace one of these if they break under warranty?  Its a hard limitation to defend I know, but all I'm saying is that its a cheaply built mic, otherwise it would cost more.  I do think its a pretty mic with its finish though.  Not ugly by any means.

3.  Just looking at the frequency response graph on their website you can tell this mic has a large presence in the upper mid to high frequency range.  Before hearing the mic you could assume this might result in a harsher brittle sound that would need to be eq'd lightly or even heavily.  I generally take freq response graphs with a grain of salt, but that big of hump in the high ranges is hard to ignore.  I would say its not bad to work with, it is a tad harsh but better that expected for its price point.  When I used it for a stereo pair room mic I was miking a tambourine and shaker (they make sound in that higher range).  I was worried about the eq but all I really had to do was multi-band compress the trouble region and nudge it lower by 2-3 db.  Then I gently applied some pultec eq at 10khz (plugin) until it sat nicely in the mix.  I know not everyone will have these exact tools.  All I can suggest is that you have a warm sounding mic pre to balance the boosted hi-end presence or be prepared to do some eq'ing in the upper range.

4.  This mic has a self noise rating of 17dba.  That would be great for a tube condenser but this is a solid state small diaphragm condenser.  Sure its not astronomically high like some other budget mics, but that's a fairly serious limitation.  What this means is you'll have to be careful with how much gain you're applying in the pre stage.  With a mic like this you'll be much better off miking your subject within a foot or two and no more.  But as I said I've used this mic for a room mic before.  It is fine to do, just realize you need to back off the gain to avoid a high noise floor (which will translate terribly into your recording).  To get around the self noise, watch your gain settings.  If you're going for lo-fi garage rock though, you could easily ignore all that advice.

Can't think of any other specific limitations I didn't cover.  Just make sure you think about that with all your mic's in your kit.  As far as additional recommendations, I'm going to assume (i do this a lot) that you don't have much money to throw around on microphones.  If that is the case I will suggest two paths to take.

1.  Do very thorough research (calling companies and engineers, read reviews, watch youtube videos) and purchase a varied set of the best budget mics (SM57, a pair of CAD GXL1200BP or similar brand, Rode NT1A or similar Large Diaphragm condenser).  Run these budget mics through a decent if not phenomenal mic preamp (tube or FET, whatever you can afford to spend the most on).  Run your budget mics into a decent pre into a decent interface into your DAW, or skip the interface and DAW if you are analog recording.  This way you can clean up the loss of fidelity from the mics with the preamps and even further with EQ.  Unfortunately its inevitable you will need to use EQ and other processing just to get most budget mics to sound good.  Its NOT the end of the world, its how the recording world works sometimes.  In some cases no eq will be necessary, realize that isn't a standard you've created that everyone else should follow, it just happens to suit your ears at the time.  That's what makes microphone research so hard, everyone has a different set of discriminating ears.

2.  The other way to go is to skip the budget mic setup (a pair of Small Diap. Condensers, One LDC, a couple dynamics) and just go for one very good mid-range to high-end LDC (Large Diaphragm Condenser).  This way you save up for only one very good mic, but one that is versatile enough to use on everything.  A good engineer knows how to mic even a drum kit with only one microphone.  If this sounds good to you, what I would suggest is getting the Rode NT1A Oktavamod from Mike Joly Engineering.  Its about $600.  If that is still too high look at vintageking.com for LDC mics in your range and do the research from there (check sweetwater and soundpure.com too).

I know this review is very long winded but I think its best to provide real-world advice instead of just a simple half-brained review that would only serve the purpose to confuse you further and make it worse.  I am a self-taught recording engineer with decent home recording experience and the thirst to learn more to become a great engineer.  I believe in the truth always when it comes to the art of recording because all the rest of the garbage coming out of peoples mouths is just lies most of the time fueled by whatever nonsense is poisoning their brains.  If you have any recording or mic questions leave a comment and maybe I could help you figure your issue out.  Thank you.

I found this little recorder in a second-hand music shop for a buck.  I wanted something I could carry around in a backpack or the glove compartment of a car instead of my more expensive recorders.  I found I was pleasantly surprised at the instrument.  I do have better sounding ABS instruments but they are not better by much so far as pitch is concerned.  This is a baroque style instrument it is tuned to A=440, which is concert pitch.  It isn't as durable as Yamaha's or even Suzuki's but I didn't expect it to be.  Thus far (a couple of years) it's still around and still sounds good.  Unfortunately, it is only one piece which makes cleaning it a bit more difficult.  I use Mi-ty Mist, and I make sure it dries well.  I certainly recommend this as a child's first recorder or one to have at home instead of having to transport the one they might have at school.
A little on the thick side. Otherwise, it's fine.
Always good to trick out your new axe! Adds a nice touch of vintage Gibson class! I knocked a star off because the one I got has an uneven engraving job in the middle of "RHYTHM."

I read a lot of reviews about mics before pulling the trigger on these (bought a pair). I found a great post with a lot of detail about how this mic is a great platform for making modifications and upgrading if you choose, but that it is also an excellent mic out of the box.
[...]

I've not run it through it's paces for recording yet, but I have tested it and it sounds great. I'll update this review after I've used it more. Just make sure you've got a preamp or interface with 48v phantom power.
Great strap. Looks great on my guitar. I only wish it had the leather lining on the underside of the strap like my other Levy's strap.
summary: Great strap. Looks great on my guitar

reviewText: Nice pattern and looks good on guitar.  Holes a bi smaller than needed. If you have a nicer guitar invest in a good quality leather strap.  More comfortable in the long run. But this is cool looking on a knock around that CA go to the beach.
What a concept, I can actually get the leather over my strap button without pliers like you need with their over hyped and over priced thick leather straps. These are very nice.
summary: So much better and easier to use than their over hyped and over priced thick leather straps.

reviewText: the strap ends are a bit thick, but they won't tear for sure, youll get a lot of wear out of it.
summary: the strap ends are a bit thick, but they won't tear for sure

reviewText: good
Comfortable and well constructed
This thing cannot remove even very light scratches on my guitar. However, it does turn the dull surface areas shiny again.
summary: Make guitars shiny, but does not remove scratches.

reviewText:
I'm a recording musician and I have worked in professional studios with professional equipment, I would say this mic compares very well to items at ten times the price point.

The only reason I gave it four stars is because when I got the item there was a dark spot on the grille (purely cosmetic) and the construction all around seems a little weak, but hell, it's a sub $100 condenser, can't really complain that much now can I?
I had been using these for years, but the Clayton Black Raven picks are my new favorite. They just sound better.
summary: Good, but the black raven is better

reviewText: NICE

This is a high quality pick but not one that I will be using very much. It is a personal preference issue, not anything that is wrong with the these picks. I normally use a fender celluloid medium flat pick, and this feels rather large when I try to use it. It really is not much larger then the Fender pick. The height is perhaps 1/16 inch (1.5mm) more, and the width about 3/16 inch (4.5mm) more.  The radius forming the sides is greater than on the Fender, so that had some impact on how if feels to me. This size thing is all a mater of personal preference, so the comments about size is not intended as a complaint. Just information. The size and stiffness of this pick may be preferable to you.
The picks I bought are 0.80mm thickness and they seem a little stiffer than the medium weight Fender picks that I normally use. If shape and size of this pick were not an issue for me, I would probably go for thinner size to get something a little more flexible.
summary: This feels big compared to the Fender flat picks that I normally use.

reviewText: works fine. As good as any other I've played

I'm a woodwind player added this to my collection. Sound is pretty good. It's not like those cheap quality models for kids. The bag that it came with isn't that great. It's a simple cotton pouch. I wish there was an actual case for recorder like my other woodwind instruments.

Like many reviewers state, there's no 'best' pick for everyone and you'll end up trying several types before you find a few that work best for your playing styles.  For me, this one is the best I've played for a general purpose pick.  I like the large grip and the 3 corners.  Also, it doesn't seem to slip as much as other picks tend to do when I play.  I can flex it a bit to make it stiffer when I need to.

As another reviewer pointed out, these picks do make a very noticeable scraping sound.  -1 star.  However, for every other reason, I'll stick with these until I find something just as comfortable and less noisy.  If they weren't so noisy, I'd easily rate these 5 stars.
summary: Best I've found so far, but ...

reviewText:
I bought two of these for use mainly in my home "studio" for drum overheads, piano, acoustic instruments etc.
Mine are nice looking and reliable. They have a lower self noise than many SDC mics at much higher price points.
I have never had any trouble with them in the studio and have even taken them into the field for  recording.
They are very useful and mine get used very often. If I had a larger budget I may have chosen a different SDC, but I'm actually I tried the GXL1200 as I have always achieved very good results. I don't really plan to replace them with more expensive SDCs for my purposes at the moment as sort of my home recording is for songwriting purposes.  If I lose one or it gets stolen, I would most likely replace it with another GXL1200.

I think they would suit most amateurs and hobbyists quite well.

I am just an amateur musician who does small projects at home for school and other activities on occasion, and this microphone is great for just such a thing. It offers a clear sound that most people would look for in a good microphone, and the quality is very nice.

Few complaints:

-The shock mount is horrible. If you're planning on getting this microphone, also plan on buying a separate shock mount for it, because the one that comes with the package has terrible, loose screw mounts [it got stripped after I tried to tighten it a little bit].
-The microphone seems to pick up more highs than lows. It may also have to do with my particular recording techniques, but I've never really had this problem with my other microphone, the Shure SM-57. It seems to be more sensitive to highs than lows. If you get this microphone, experiment around with it a bit.
summary: It's pretty good for beginning/intermediate projects

reviewText: Great bag. Nice and light and good handles. Add some rope on each side for side handles.

I use this mic is used primarily for micing acoustic guitar or mandolin at small coffee house type gigs.  The sound is quite good, and its sensitivity allows the instrument to be some distance from the mic, which can be handy if you're trying to mic several instruments at once from one mic.  I have another mic of this size, an SE-1, and the two are comparable.  I've not had any problems with mine, and would buy another if this one were to disappear (which sometimes happens at gigs!)
Really helpful when transporting drum set.
Nice strap. Well made.
My daughter loves this strap. seems okay made and worth it.

The bag is very durably constructed and can hold up to wear and tear from shows. But do yourself a favor and shell the extra money for a bag with wheels. Carrying a full load of hardware is exhausting.
summary: Great bag for people with a small amount of hardware

reviewText: Got this to carry a Ampeg PF 800 amp. Returned the amp. I've used this on short overnight gigs to carry pair of pants and a few shirts.

Great, well made, lightweight bag!  I bought this bag as a lightweight gear bag for drum stands and gear with the aim of not having to break down all the stands.  It works great for that, but could use some handles on the ends, otherwise I would give it a five star rating.  I am now using the bag for my speaker stands.

I have used many different drum hardware carts and bags over the years, and this has one big advantage- because it stands upright, I can load and unload it while standing or sitting, which saves a lot of wear and tear on my back. It holds 2 snare stands (I mount my 1 small tom on a snare stand), 3 cymbal stands, hi hat stand, and my throne, including seat. It is not big enough for some throne seats, such as the Soundseat. It also cannot hold my base drum pedal. It has several outer pockets for stick bags or other small stands, mics, floor tom legs, and small percussion instruments like a cowbell. I have owned several of these in the past and was disappointed in the poor construction. On one the wheels broke and I had to replace them. On another the wooden base began cracking, and the canvas material began to fray and small holes appeared. But, I'm still using it to save my back!
Decent case for the price.  It just fits my old Electra.  Looks decent.  Not sure how it would hold up to constant carry and use as a gig case.  Time may tell.
summary: Pretty nice case for the price.

reviewText: I like the sturdiness of the fabric and zippers. So far, haven't had any problems with rips or broken zippers. In retrospect, I wish I had thrown down the extra money for something with wheels...but that's my own fault :(
I wouldn't order again. The leather is too think and too much of a pain to get over button
This doesn't stand up but neither do a lot of hard cases. I really like the zippered compartment on top where I store written lyrics and such.
summary: We'll made. It holds Teles or Strats.

reviewText: I was building custom Fender Strats ... buying the Fender wood cases and then protecting these in storage by buying keyboard gig bags. No more! Now I buy these cases and do not have to worry about the case getting scuffing or tolex getting ripped much less the guitar getting damaged. Great protection for Strats and I have also used these for the new PRS Zach Myers SE. The main body bout may seem tight but it fits great. One less point for the weak zipper tabs that can and have snapped off in the past. These are great compact light cases for Strats and PRS guitars.
summary: Great compact light case for Strats and PRS guitars

reviewText: while it works, it is about as twice as thick as a solid case. But I guess it needs that to be lighter. I am not sure I would buy another one of these when compared to the price of a hard shell.
summary: I am not sure I would buy another one

reviewText: comfortable and pretty

Didn't want to spend lots of money, but wanted a good product. This case fits my needs. Both of my basses fit into this case - a 35" scale Ibanez BTB and a 34" scale ESP/LTD Surveyor, both 5 strings. Only giving it 4 stars as the zipper tends to hang up in one spot because it wasn't attached to the case body halves accurately. But a nice light weight case, none the less. Looking to get another one for my new Strat!

OK, so I just moved on from this case and in some ways I miss it.  I thought I should come back and put some review info in here.

This is a fine case.  I like it.  I can't yet bring myself to let it go.  The only problem I had with it was its size.  It is physically very big due to the rectangular size.  The location where the shoulder strap connects always bothered me too as I had to unhook one side every time I opened the case.  I will add I replaced the shoulder strap immediately upon its arrival cause the one which came with it was cheap.  Adequate I guess but minimal.

OK, that is most of the negatives.  I still liked it and and used it regularly.  It protected my guitar well (PRS Semi Hollow just fit) and I really liked the inside dual storage boxes on each side of the neck.  I used the outside pouches heavily also.

I replaced it for one reason only, it is big.  Note I didn't say too big cause you might love it.

Now, I've moved to another case with backpack straps.  I miss the shoulder strap a lot and will likely customize the new one to add one soon if I stick with it.

The two things I miss most about it now are the inside storage which my new case does not have AND the weight.  This thing is so light that you simply get used to it and don't realize how light it is.  Everything else I carry now seems very heavy.

I may go back.  Only time will tell.

For the price, I think this is an excellent case.  Maybe I'll buy another guitar just so I can justify keeping it ;-)
summary: Loved it except for size (rectangular size)

reviewText: This is about as nice of a strap as you could expect.  Maybe something thicker would be better, but I haven't had any issues with it cutting into me.
summary: This is about as nice of a strap as you could expect

reviewText: Well made. As good as any you find in guitar stores.

Installed this into an Epiphone Les Paul Standard Plus. Originally replaced the pickups with uncovered Seymour Duncan SH-1's, though the guitar can with covered pickups.

Liked it for a while (5 years, to be exact), but, having bought a 2012 Gibson LP Standard Plus, and it having burstbucker pro's, I figured I'd show the Epi a bit of love and swap to some covered pickups, and, why not Gibson 57 Cl/Cl+?

Yes, I know, I could have just bought some covers, soldered them on, and potted them myself, but, that's a PITA I didn't want to deal with. These are already potted.

Removed the SH1's, installed these, and there's a difference - these are a bit 'hotter'. Granted, that could be pickup-string distance differences, but, overall, I still think it was an improvement. No matter, asthetically the Epi looks better, though tonally it can't touch the Gibson.

Still, as a grab it, play the crap out of it and put it away wet, the Epi is a bit more friendly to that kind of treatment, and if i ding it, I won't shed nearly as many tears...hence why I still have it....plus it's a good comparison to what I thought was a pretty good guitar...

I know these aren't Burstbuckers (1/2/3) or Burstbucker Pros, BBs are "scatter-wound", which I guess means they're wound randomly (but probably the same number of turns), and unevenly wound coils - meaning one coil has more winds than the other, which give the BB's more "bite", where the 57 CL/CL+ would be more "smooth/creamy"

-1 star because they ARE so expensive, even though here they had the best price I could find easily.
There's not much to say about this, it's a nice guitar strap.  I'd buy again and recommend it to others.
Works fairly well.
It works perfectly. It's what I was looking for. I like this brand and the products they make. You should give it a try.
good slide, it was affordable.  it gets the job done.  It was a little smaller than I wanted it to be
love it
love it

This is rilly, rilly cool looking AND it is certified suitable for hootenannies.  No kidding.  My only problem is that I had to drill out the button holes because, even with my ham hands, I couldn't force the stiff leather ends over the strap buttons and a Fender strap lock wouldn't fit either---till I fixed them.

I have two and they both keep on ticking---hootenanny after hootenanny!
summary: How can your nanny hoot without one?

reviewText: A little small for my finger, but does the job nicely.

Nicely made strong strap with colorful pattern. It fits my ovation quite snuggly, I bought some retainers, but found them unnecessary so far. I couldn't remove this strap if I wanted to, well I could but its just too much work. So it will stay where it belongs for a few years at least.

The only thing I don't like about this strap is the edge of the strap is a bit abrasive on my bare neck. Not a problem in the cooler months when I'm prone to sweaters and such, but in the summer it takes a bit of getting used to. It's made of a canvassy cotton, so its strong, but its also a little rough. I'm going to try waxing the edge with canning wax or candle wax and see if that smooths it down a bit.

It is a very nice strap and will last years. I like it almost as much as my 40 year old ACE strap, which is much softer due to 40 odd years of use and abuse by a multitude of musicians. But finding an old ACE for anything close to this price is a fools journey.

Buy one, then keep your eyes out for a hootenanny. You'll be ready.....
summary: solid strap will support you in all your efforts.

reviewText: They sound good, I replaced epi classic pro's and they are clearer and sound better but I expected them to be much better, they are nicer but I'm not sure by how much.
summary: They sound good, I replaced epi classic pro's and they are ...

reviewText: sounds good in the neck position of my ES335 copy, could be a little brighter. I wrote that awhile back and am adding here. I bought the pickup for around 90.00 the current prices are outrageous! Anyway, I decided to change the wiring from 2 to 4 conductor so I could do series /parallel and coil splits. Now the guitar is what I want! Also changed cap values to .022 bridge .017 neck. And 50s wiring. This is the ticket I don't think I could improve on this guitar, I am going to wire my 2014 Les Paul the same way. Also had to reverse a magnet to get what I wanted. No hum at all with both pickups on and in single coil mode. Sounds very good. Hit a couple switches and back to hi gain overdrive AC/DC heaven. Then back to clean jingle jangle country. It does it all now. Took a lot of research to figure out the wiring scheme.
summary: Great pickup now that I rewired for 4 conductor. Do not get the 2 conductor model if you want clean and overdrive, it's too hot.

reviewText: I have big hands for a short man.  I don't quite reach 5'8", but need an XL glove.  When I ordered the slide, I read that it was medium wall thickness but thought it was large in diameter, which would work good from my second knuckle up on my ring finger.  Well, it won't make it to my second knuckle on my pinky without needing soap to get it off,  I believe it is both medium in thickness and medium in size.  maybe I should have read the fine print. I think I'll gift it to my nephew.
summary: Does What It's Supposed To But Is Too Small for Me

reviewText: heavy duty it looks cool. i need to practice but it looks like it will last a few life times
summary: heavy duty it looks cool. i need to practice but it looks like ...

reviewText: Bought as a gift for my son, and he's very pleased with it. What can you say? It's a guitar strap, it does the job, and looks good. And $20 for a Levy's Leather strap is a good deal. I got the gold, and it's good-looking without being garish.
Nice slide. I only just picked up slide guitar myself so I might not know what a great slide is. Works for me.
Nice sound with a little tweaking in post.

I got this preamp to go with a passive piezo Fishman bridge which I had put on my Godin 5th Avenue, it pretty tinny without it.  I'm excited to own this, it works great with my guitar and ukulele that have electric electronics.  I'm satisfied with how my 5th Avenue sounds now, this preamp was what it needed.

I'm sure there are better mics out there, but I haven't used one.  This mic is clear and sounds great.  I'd recommend it to anyone doing recording at home.  It seems well made.

Edit: Above was my original review.  Now that I've tried some other LDCs, I'd say this is the worst I've used.  It's just not as clear as the Rose NT1a or the Blue Spark and it's much noisier.  For the money it is still a good mic, but if you're will to spend 3-4 times as much money, you can do better.

Too bad Amazon won't let you link to recordings.  The difference between this and better mics is not too hard to hear.
Gift and is enjoyed by user.

The guitar is alright, I got it for a beginner class. However the bridge needed replacement quickly. The stock strings were actually alright for over a month. Stayed in tune well, other then when the bridge started going.
summary: Nice guitar but has its ups and downs

reviewText: Nicer

Wonderful guitar.  The fit and finish is unbeatable.  The packaging is great.  The strings were dead sounding out of the box so I changed them out for a Phosphor Bronze Light gauge set and the instrument instantly came alive.  The original strings were a shiny yellow color.  That must be the wrong alloy for guitar strings.  Now I have the best sounding and playing guitar at this price point.
summary: Wonderful guitar. The fit and finish is unbeatable

reviewText:
Great for a starter guitar or even for non-professional musicians. It has a deep tone and has a loud enough sound. Just be sure to purchase a new set of strings along with this. The high E string broke on me when I was tuning it. Probably due to non-usage when stocked in the warehouse of something.
Recommended!
not bad for the money
Signal is not quite as hot as the C03, but a good mic.

A nice light little recorder - tone is a little thin, and it is very sensitive to volume of air - too much and it jumps an octave - more sensitive than I remember my wood recorder as being. Lots of fun, however,  playing do a deer and oats peas beans and barley!
summary: A nice little recorder - a bit sensitive to air volume

reviewText: I got this because it was so cheap, it is easy to play, looks good and sounds good.  And, blue is one of my favorite colors :)

This is NOT my first guitar. Nor am I breathless Epiphone supporter shouting how this guitar is the sonic equal of Taylors and Martins. It's not. Here's what it is: An exceedingly well-constucted, AMAZINGLY playable guitar. Fit, finish, feel and action were all VERY nice... Sound on the other hand? Let's face it. It's plywood all around. It SOUNDS like plywood. But that doesn't distract from the fact that it's a great guitar for $100 bucks.

It's a fine "first" guitar. It's a great beach/camping/cabin guitar. Leave it in your car to practice at lunch. Leave it in the office. ANY guitar is better than no guitar... And this guitar is better than a LOT of other entry level guitars.

Seriously consider changing strings the second you take it out of the box... New, premium strings DO make a difference.

If your expectations are for a playable, rugged, affordable guitar you won't be disappointed. If sound quality is your primary concern, well... You are going to have to spend more than a hundred bucks to be happy.

For my desired application, this guitar was great... I'm very happy with it and would buy it again in a heartbeat.

I haven't picked up a guitar in the better part of 10 years.  My expectations on this weren't very high, based on the price.  I turned out to be pleasantly surprised when the guitar got here.

For starters, It is very nice looking.  It feels well built and doesn't give the impression that it's a cheap guitar.

The guitar stays in tune very well.  I picked up a Snark tuner and I find I have to fine tune it once in a while but usually I can just pick it up and start strumming.

The sound isn't bad, but it's not outstanding either.  It is a bit bright sounding, it's not a really big deep tone.  But it still sounds pretty good and definitely beat my expectations in this regards.  I suspect that changing the strings from the factory strings it came with could help the overall sound but I haven't bothered yet.

I used to only own electric guitars and other than goofing around with the occasional acoustic I didn't have much experience with them.  The action on this doesn't feel like an electric but it's not so high that I have any real difficulty playing it.  I have medium sized hands and the neck isn't too large to comfortably play typical open and bar chords.

If my interest stays and I continue to play I might buy something that sounds better, but this has been perfect for me getting back into playing after a long hiatus without getting deeply invested in an expensive instrument.

I purchased one of these from Guitar Center.  Overall, I think it's a good value for the price  I did follow everyone's advise and replaced the strings.  The sound seems okay; however, I'm picking up a little buzz on the first string, third fret while strumming a G chord. I'm hoping it will work itself out as the strings settle.  I will say that I was pleasantly surprised with the action on this guitar.  Right out of the box, the strings are relatively low to the fret board, which is unusual for a low end guitar.  I asked the tech if there was anything he could do to improve its performance.  The stuff he talked about was minor, so there wasn't really any need for a setup.

I would recommend this guitar for someone who is a beginner, or for someone who just wants something that won't break the bank.  Would be a great guitar for camping, beach, or wherever.  No worries.

UPDATE: It turns out that the fourth fret was high.  Not wanting to deal with fixing it, I returned to Guitar Center where they swapped it out for a DR 150.  Now I have a high fourteenth fret on the new guitar.  My advise to anyone who wants to buy one of these guitars is to play all the frets and check for buzz. I still think they're decent guitars, but there is an apparent issue with the frets not being consistently at the same height.
summary: Not a bad guitar for the price.

reviewText:
I bought this for my step dad for Christmas. He wanted to learn to play. I thought "Well, if he gives up on it, I'm only out a hundred bucks.".
When it arrived, I opened the box to make sure it wasn't in pieces before wrapping it. I was blown away. The finish was flawless. The fret ends were nicely dressed. The neck was straight. There was no glue squeezing out from under the bracing. The headstock has an actual inlay instead of a decal.
It sounded a little tinny with stock strings, as other reviews here have noted, so I put some Martin 9s on it to ease him into callused fingers. It sounds really good! My own acoustic is a Seagull with a cedar top. The spruce on the Epiphone is a little brighter, but not at all harsh. The neck is surprisingly thin and narrow, which I don't prefer, but is good for smaller hands. It's a lot like an Ibanez electric neck, in fact.
It may not project like a more expensive acoustic, but I wasn't at all displeased with its tone, which will only improve with time. If you're looking for a good deal on a beginners acoustic, look no further.

Update: A year later, and he DID give up on it. Actually, he never really tried. I took it home, because it was making him feel guilty, just sitting in the corner. It really has good tone, and stays in tune beautifully for stock Epi tuners! A heavier gauge string improves its sound.
It won't replace my own acoustic but, as a first guitar, backup for when other players come over, or a campfire guitar, it's a fantastic buy.

4 stars for the quality to price ratio. It's obviously not in the same league as a 600 dollar Takamine, let alone a 2,400 dollar Gibson, but is well worth the 99 bucks I paid for it, and then some. If you decide that the guitar isn't for you, you could always get your money back out of it, as long as you potential buyer gets to play it first. They'll be as surprised as I was.
summary: 4 stars for a hundred dollar guitar?

reviewText:
I would give this five stars, and probably should for the price. The pros, this is a fairly well-tuned recorder that is easier to play, easier to blow, than the Ivory Yamaha German-fingered 20-series model that I lost in my recent move. Nice tone, solid feel.
Cons, (which I only mention because I also bought a Yamaha YRS-302B Soprano Recorder, which cost about $15 more), this recorder, like all soprano recorders, tends to sound a bit like a whistle, while the the 30-series mentioned above, sounds slightly less like a whistle, more like an instrument.
Another con, I can play more than two-hundred tunes by ear, and am always picking out new ones, and when picking out the notes, it is imperative that the notes be true, or you get thrown off, the process takes longer. To my ear, in comparison to more expensive Yamaha soprano recorders, and larger alto and tenor models, the low F on this one is just a tiny bit higher than it should be, another reason for the four stars, but hey, for the price!
Before buying this model I asked a question here on Amazon about the colored translucent models, and was told by a consort player that these translucent ones are just as good as the ivory ones, and as I found, and say above, better than some.
I have been playing recorder for about 15 years and played clarinet for more than a year before that, and I like this okay.
I sit in my kitchen while dinner is cooking, and have a jam -- I play mostly jazz pop.
summary: Excellent value, lots of fun even for experienced players

reviewText: These are listed as cymbal mallets, but I decided to experiment and I am currently using on my Conga, Bongo, Timbale set up and like the tone I can get without worry of damaging the heads going from one drum to the next.

This is a very nice recorder.  It came in a clear protective case, which is great.  There were some very, very brief instructions that I could not understand at all, so I'm going to have to go on the internet to look for better instructions.  This is why I'm not giving it 5 starts.
Good basic cymbal carrier.  Could use a couple more dividers.
sounds pretty good but head is a little too hard
I leave theses in my studio for other drummers. They look well made and sound good. I like the yarn tip.

These are very high-quality mallets. I was looking for something a bit softer, so maybe I'll wrap some other yarn on them. It does make for good cymbal swells, but I hear more impact than I was imagining. They feel well-balanced and they are definitely quality material.
summary: Very well made. I took one star off because I hoped they would be a little softer.

reviewText: I love this thing. It's got great tone! The only thing I'd mention is that the on/off switch isn't easy to use. Because the button is near them knobs, if you are trying to turn it on or off quickly, you need good aim. I like the big flat switch from the older versions.

cheaper than a Jaspo0rt backpack, this bag does the job and does it well. Has individual sleeves for each cymbal (by sleeves I mean thin sheet of synthetic nylon). Straps look like they'll last a while, shipped fast. Wish it had padding at the bottom. I set it down and think I damaged the cymbals... wasn't expecting them to just rest on the floor. Not well designed on the bottom. Hihat pouch is handy. comes with caribeaner, not sure why. Zildjian got a deal on caribeaners and just threw one on there for no apparent reason, maybe should have padded the bottom instead?
summary: Surprisingly well made for the price!

reviewText:
Installed this into an Epiphone Les Paul Standard Plus. Originally replaced the pickups with uncovered Seymour Duncan SH-1's, though the guitar can with covered pickups.

Liked it for a while (5 years, to be exact), but, having bought a 2012 Gibson LP Standard Plus, and it having burstbucker pro's, I figured I'd show the Epi a bit of love and swap to some covered pickups, and, why not Gibson 57 Cl/Cl+?

Yes, I know, I could have just bought some covers, soldered them on, and potted them myself, but, that's a PITA I didn't want to deal with. These are already potted.

Removed the SH1's, installed these, and there's a difference - these are a bit 'hotter'. Granted, that could be pickup-string distance differences, but, overall, I still think it was an improvement. No matter, asthetically the Epi looks better, though tonally it can't touch the Gibson.

Still, as a grab it, play the crap out of it and put it away wet, the Epi is a bit more friendly to that kind of treatment, and if i ding it, I won't shed nearly as many tears...hence why I still have it....plus it's a good comparison to what I thought was a pretty good guitar...

I know these aren't Burstbuckers (1/2/3) or Burstbucker Pros, BBs are "scatter-wound", which I guess means they're wound randomly (but probably the same number of turns), and unevenly wound coils - meaning one coil has more winds than the other, which give the BB's more "bite", where the 57 CL/CL+ would be more "smooth/creamy"

-1 star because they ARE so expensive, even though here they had the best price I could find easily.

These Danelectro pedals are great quality for the money. I use this pedal behind my dirt pedals for added flexibility and bringing out some more "brilliance" to the tone. The case is plastic, not very attractive, and perhaps not very sturdy. Also the button to push down for the effect leaves a bit to be desired -- it doesn't feel very solid. But I intend to use this more for recording than live use, so I'm not worried about that. Anyway, there aren't many EQ's on the market, and for the price, it can't be beat. I would recommend it.
Works well. Just wish they offered pedal with metal casing.
For your money I can't recommend the EQ enough. It's cheap, works well, and is small enough as to not clutter your pedalboard.
Not much to say here. It looks good and the chrome plating looks like its of good quality, and it does what it is supposed to do.
summary: What can i say? I'ts a chromed bracket.

reviewText:
Well, just got one of this and been messin with it for a couple of hours...

I still think it takes a bit of brightness on bypass but when it's on it's great! I've been thinking on using it mainly as a boost for leads but it sounds so much better with it i can't seem to turn it off!

it's light, small and it looks well built but only time will tell how resistent it is but hey for 30 bucks it's a great deal!

This is a good EQ for an excelent price, not an excelent EQ so i give it a 4 out of 5 and look forward to testing some others danelectro pedals.

I've been useing this pedal for several years and it does the job.  Yes, it could be metal, and I wish the button gave a satisfying 'click' when I step on it.  For under thirty clams I can look past these things.  I have not had any issues with noise (crackling or oscillation).  I really have no complaints at all with it's performance so I am glad I didn't shell out 3-4X more money so I can feel more secure when I unlatch my pedal board in front of gear-snobs.  I don't think I need to run this pedal with every amp I own but it does a great job 'opening up the sound' of boxy or dark sounding amps.  When I run it in the effects loop of my Palomino V8 (great little practice amp btw) that little amp sounds HUGE.  Also great in front of my Blues Jr.  If you own an amp with a single tone knob (Pro Jr, Valve Jr etc) or if you find your tone stack lacking responsiveness you owe it to yourself to buy one of these. Even if you are satisfied with the responsiveness of your amp's controls, this pedal can double as a volume boost when playing lead.  Once my sound is dialed in, I leave typically leave it on and forget about it.  It's also pretty indespensible for shaping the sound of your amplified acoustic guitar-

I bought this EQ pedal after reading many good reviews, and it is my first EQ pedal.  I'm glad I did:  It really cleans up the sound, and in my case, if you're using a thick/fuzzy distortion (a la Silversun Pickups, My Bloody Valentine) and gives a nice boost for guitar solos.  I wouldn't say the difference is gigantic, but it's definitely there.

Seriously, this is a great pedal. I can't improve upon what others have said, but I will mention a few points.

1. I use this after the preamp or dirt boxes for a lead tone, or to add more crunch to my Fender Frontman 212 when inserted in the effects loop. It's run before time based effects (delay, phaser, etc) for me.
2. I sometimes use it before the distortion as a clean booster, while focusing one of the sliders to boost a few frequencies.
3. If it gets noisy or "self oscillates" after a while, change the battery to a fresh one. Better yet, use an AC adapter.

I found out about the last issue after reading a few Harmony Central reviews. Otherwise, it's been on my setup for about seven years. I take care of my stuff.
I'd say this is made to pretty good specs. I didn't have any issues with install.

I bought this bracket for my Epiphone Dot guitar, and I chose it because the chrome looks better than other materials. My only concern with it is that it doesn't lift the pickguard as far from the body as other brackets. It's not hat big of a deal, it's just not the same as other Epi Dots and Gibson 335s.
summary: and I chose it because the chrome looks better than other materials

reviewText: This bag is the absolute perfect size for me to carry my hand percussion instruments, my vocal and horn mics and still has plenty of room for cables, patches and other gear, the side pocket is large enough to hold various things like batteries and other items. The reason for only 4 stars is that I wish the divider velcro would stay better adhered and the shoulder carry strap is lined up awkwardly and is taking some getting used to. But I still highly recommend this great bag! It is sturdy and rugged and a decent price!
Husband uses these strings for years, wants to buy single strings and not whole sets. Where can we just buy single strings?
summary: Husband uses these strings for years, wants to buy ...

reviewText: great amp, battery lasts forever

First let me say that the sound, portability, and design simplicity all get 5 starts.  My unit arrive with a defective battery installation. (One battery was lose, its red lead was off and not crimped enough to stay connected, and the wood bracket was screwed in improperly, with the screws missing the wood just enough to split the wood.)  But the 1 missing star is for the Amazon link.  Having figured out the problems,  I decided to go online and do an exchange.  To my surprise the Amazon link simply said , "Hazardous  material, cannot return".  There was no link to chat or call, or e-mail on this page, so I repaired the unit (removed, then mounted the battery properly, crimped the red connector so it would hold properly, and  drilled new holes in the wooded bracket and reinstalled it.  If you are reading this and considering this purchase via Amazon, you may want to make sure you know where the Amazon "Contact" page is located, as I am sure they are willing advise you in some way.  PS: love the sound of the unit.
summary: great unit but battery installation issue

reviewText: One star off for it getting so hot! Other than that, it works good. I recommend hanging this unit if you buy it!!  I ran it all night long, still works. I will update this if things change.
summary: It works, but gets way hot.

reviewText: This is a great drum stick holder bag!! I have four sets of drum sticks and it holds all of the perfectly and have room for a few more drum sticks if needed. It is also light weight and that is great for carrying them around. Love it!!

Well made and durable. The price you'll pay for this is a bargain. Good size for most drummers, but if you carry a large selection of sticks, that includes brushes, mallets, and such, you may need something larger. I've had mine for years, carried it around from gig to gig , thrown it in the washing machine a time or two, and the only flaw I can note is that the Zildjian logo has worn off some.

It's a decent fog machine for a small room or house/garage party. I took it to a medium sized room and it struggled to fill the room up. I had to keep on pressing the button constantly to have a decent fog effect. But for the price you can't beat this if you're a beginner DJ. I upgraded to the Chauvet DJ Hurricane Haze 1D and it's a world of a difference but it's also 3x the price.
Works pretty good. Use 2 of them on stage with band. It won't cover the stage but it puts out a decent amount of fog. If you have a large area I would suggest a bigger one.
Good for the price.

I got about 30 seconds of fog before the unit stopped for another 30 seconds to warm up the fog juice before I could use it again. If you need longer fog duration, get a 700 watt unit. Otherwise the unit worked fine.

love the gold embroidered Zildian name on front AND back. Bag seems like decent quality but I'll know more over time of use. The smell initially was intense but subsided over a weeks time in my studio.
summary: love the gold embroidered Zildian name on front AND back

reviewText: I bought this for Halloween and it worked pretty well. It doesn't push out a large volume all at once but will fill an area pretty well after about 10 minutes. This model does not have a timer controller, only a manual button. I "cheated" and wrapped a zip tie around the controller, holding the manual button down. With the button held down, the fog machine Will pump out fog for about 10-15 seconds then stop to cool down and go again when it's ready. Using it this way did drain the reservoir in about 90-110 minutes so keep an eye on the tanks next year I will most likely find a way to attach a larger bottle to the machine to let it pull from a larger resevoir.
summary: Great fog machine, small tank resevoir

reviewText: Give out a lot of good fog. Just wish it had a wireless remote.

I needed a fog machine for a Halloween event....I used to own a DJ company so I have a background in this type of equipment. When I read the reviews of this little (Yes..its pretty small!) machine I thought I would give it a shot! The price was right! So here are my thoughts...
A- As I posted above...don't let the "700" fool you and let it fool you into thinking this is a 700 watt unit.....In the spec's I read it draws a little OVER 400 watts! Most machines in this class were right at 400W...since this was more (I think closer to 500W) I picked it. It is good for SMALLER spaces or if you are ok with shorter shots of fog that will dissipate quickly...the larger room is OK....
B- It WON'T run continuously but that is normal for even larger machines! If you want this option...be prepared to pay for it.....
C- The remote has a LONGER cord! NICE! But the unit has a shorter power cord.....
D- Recovery time was strange! Sometimes it took a few (3) minutes...other times longer! (5-6)
The bottom line....if you want a neat little machine and don't want to spend a bunch.....give it a try! If you want to MAKE SOME FOG...use it in larger room....use it outdoors....take the step UP and spend some money on a 1000W or true professional unit....
summary: 700 does not = 700 Watts but...there are some positives of this machine!

reviewText: LOOKS TO SMALL, BUT REALLY WORKS GREAT. A LOTS OF FOG.
summary: BUT REALLY WORKS GREAT. A LOTS OF FOG

reviewText: I purchased a used one for recording direct, then found out that it needs a cabinet simulator to sound good. Mine is an older model with the 1/8" power jack, so I don't know if they updated the cab sim since then. In order to get a good recorded tone, I need to use the speaker sim on my digitech hot head, or some vst plug-ins. It is very well built, has a lot of tone options, and with a cab sim it sounds very much like a mic'ed amp, but I prefer the character series because they sound more realistic to me.
good
The thing works but gets VERY hot very quickly. I'm not sure if it's a hazard or anything but we just used it a few pumps then turned it off.

reviewText:
It's a good fog machine - it puts out sufficient fog that makes an outdoor setting about 87% more spooky.

My main complaint with the machine is that the fog button MUST be pressed before it generates fog.  It would be nice to have some kind of a continuous setting on it, or something similar where I don't have to stand there holding the button down.  Even better would be a non-binary setting so instead of either off or 100% on it could do different fog amounts.

That said, I'm sure such features exist in more expensive fog machines, and this is not an expensive fog machine.  For what it is though, it works well.  I like it.

reviewText:
So I bought a couple of these for use as tom tom mics, as they receive great reviews for this use.  For such a low cost mic, they are very versatile with a continuously variable polar pattern that can be dialled up using a knob recessed into the mic body.  They appear to use a K67 style, center terminated capsule.  They're a little bright up top, but not annoyingly so.  I've read that these mics don't excel as vocal mics, but in my own shoot-outs, I think they are up to the task and make perfectly serviceable vocal mics.  These mics do demand a decent phantom power supply, as they use an op-amp based head amp that draws more current than your typical FET based mic, so if you are going to use them with a soundcard that has build-in preamps, make sure it can deliver a full 48V with sufficient current.  The up-side is that the op-amp based electronics are nice and quiet, giving the mic a nice low noise floor, so it's suitable for quiet sources.

My only real gripe is that the plastic carrying case is ridiculously large, taking up twice the storage space it should and making the mic somewhat expensive to ship.  Other than that, the mic easily earns 4 out of 5 stars for quality and value and usability.  It's a swiss army knife and will find a lot of uses in my studio.

so this mic is pretty versatile. sounds great on omni with my acoustic guitar, it records my amplifier very well as a room mic with the pad switch, also sounds pretty decent on vocals set to cardioid. still testing on the drums, but so far, nothing to complain about. i will say that i had to send the first one i got to CAD because it was buzzing when you'd touch the dial, they sent me a brand new one, and it is fine.

For a low cost entry level machine, it performed well.  Warm up cycles weren't excessively long.  Fog production was consistently thick and reliable.  The small size made it easy to hide.  I was able to push large amounts of fog through a homemade chiller with ease.  Although the reservoir looks small, it was good for almost two hours before refilling.  My only regret is that I didn't get a machine with a timer.  Having to hit the button all night on Halloween got old fast.  Next year I'll cut off the manual button and add my own timer.  Still a good deal though.

So far it's holding up better than the cheapo Halloween fog machine I bought at a pretty popular general store on clearance. However the fog that comes with this machine is super weak.  Doesn't hang around long and is pretty thin.  Probably just the sample stuff - hoping other fog mixtures will be better.  As for the machine itself, it's sturdy and does the job so far!  The wired remote is pretty long and has a magnet on the back.  Wish it was wireless, but you can't have everything for $36.99.
summary: Solid! But you'll want some different fluid.

reviewText:
I have had this fog machine for a few weeks, and it works very nicely.  It did make a loud noise the first time I used it, but that was the only time it made any bothersome noises.  It generates a nice, thick fog, (I am using the Chauvet Fog Fluid that came with the machine), and it warms up pretty quickly, (about 5-10 minutes or so).  It completely fills my 9x17 recording studio with fog very quickly.

I would be happier with the machine if it had an on/off switch; I have to unplug it to power it off.  I would also be happier with it if I could use it with a timer-remote, but it is not compatible with the Chauvet Fogger Timer Remote, so I guess I am out of luck with that.

I am worried that it will not last too long, because of the negative reviews of this nature that I have read, but it still works for me.

Bottom line: the Chauvet Hurricane 700 Fog Machine is a functional little unit that works pretty well for my application.
summary: Seems like a very nice fog machine, thus far

reviewText:
I ordered this despite some of the down playing review, but I got to admit.  It's a nice little foger.  First off, it doesn't put out much fog.  Which has it's pros and cons.
Cons:
Doesn't put out a big volume of fog
The remote only has one button "fog" you must hold down the button to make fog come out. (not a toggle switch)
Only a ten foot cord on remote.

Pros:
Doesn't put out much fog( so your not shooting a big cloud at your audience but instead a constant haze)
Small and light weight
Comes with a pint of good Chauvet fog fluid

If you don't want to press the bottom every two min just flip the remote over and put a weight on top, then it's on like auto fog mode.  Just watch your fog fluid levels.
I recommend this, but I recommend you get more than 1.  2 might work, 3 would be good, 4 would be amazing.
Like I said, people don't like big clouds of fog shooting at them, this machine just puts out a very fast wisp of fog, but enough to accent your lights.
This is a good set of picks.... the color is a little different but they are good quality for the price... a little larger than your average pick
Nice tone!

This is a good stand, and it really is tall!  The clamps are plastic, but everything else is metal.  The picture shows the stand at about 8 feet, it goes much taller so your lights are above the crowds heads (much better then blasting a laser show into someones eyes).  If you want a decent stand, this one should make you happy.

I gave it four stars because I'm very anal and like to reserve five star ratings for mind blowing products.  This is a good product, but it should be for the price you have to pay for it.

And if you plan to have this next to your dance floor where people can bump the stand, you should get a safety cable.  You don't want all your lights falling over on your friends head.

This is a rugged great lighting tripod that will support a fair amount of weight safely.  The only issue I had was there wasn't detailed instructions on how to set it up.  One of the extensions was actually inside a part of the unit and it took some time for me to actually find that part to make it all come together.  Overall great product just wished they had done a little bit better on the instructions.

I played a AC30 a couple of weeks before I bought this amp, and it's because I was hooked on the clean VOX sound. I read a lot of reviews and did my research and it seemed like this amp would be the best for me. I'm living in a college apartment so I didn't want to go too big and annoy my neighbors. I also didn't have much of a budget for a guitar amp, so I decided to buy low. The package came in a couple of days later and I opened it up and was amazed at the size of this thing! The picture makes it look like an eraser but it's the size of a man's shoebox. The clean channel sounds unbelievably clean. I couldn't help but compare it to my old Ibanez IBZ-10 Tone Blaster Amp which sounded like there was a perpetual colony of bees hiving inside the speaker. The volume gets pretty loud even for its size and it still maintains that clean sound even at 12 gain and 12 volume. The "overdrive" setting is cool too. I haven't tinkered with that one too much, but it's fun to play "Johnny B. Goode" on.

I didn't want to buy an amp that had all of the shiny bells and whistles that fall off after the first month. I wanted a quality amp for a low price, and I got it. You can always buy pedals to get all those cool sounds, and I plan on doing that too, but you need a good amp with a good clean channel like this one before you start getting into other effects. I would definitely recommend this amp to the college apartment dweller and to anyone else who wants an amazing practice amp.

I'm not sure if this would be the best gigging amp though, but then again, I don't see myself gigging anytime soon.
summary: Amazing Amp for the Apartment College Dweller on a Shoe String Budget

reviewText: I just wanted a cheap practice amp and the VOX is perfect. Sounds great and can be quite loud with gain and overdrive on. Also looks really cool( vintage) looks like something the Beatles would have  used. This is the perfect practice amp for bedroom or living room.  First of all, it's small.  Second, it sounds great!  The clean channel provides classic Vox sound and the dirty channel is pretty good as well.  Would be nice if it had reverb, but for $69, I can't complain.  Yes, this is a great practice amp!  I bet running two of these in stereo with a Boss chorus pedal would sound fantastic.
